DOC.HEAD: Government Survives First Parliamentary No-Confidence Vote
Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with quotes by Gorbachev and Ryzhkov; Picks up 10th graf, `The vote ...'; ADDS 1 graf at end with other action.
DOC.TEXT: Parliament put the government through its first no-confidence vote today over an economic reform plan that retains heavy central planning, but Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and his ministers easily survived. In the dramatic confrontation, the normally sophisticated Ryzhkov's voice cracked with emotion as he pleaded for support. Progressives have criticized his economic package as inadequate to the task of ending a grave economic crisis. They say it doesn't go far enough to overhaul a plodding bureaucractic system and encourage greater productivity and efficiency by embracing free market mechanisms. ``The Congress should not avoid making an evaluation. It must express its firm position: either to support the government's proposals, of course considering the remarks made here, or some other formulation,'' Ryzhkov told the 2,250 members of the Congress of People's Deputies, the Soviet Parliament. After his appeal, the no-confidence motion was rejected by tally of 1,685 to 199 with 99 abstentions. The ruling Communists hold 87 percent of the chamber's seats. Yuri Andreev, a parliamentarian from Moscow, proposed the no-confidence vote after a heated debate in which progressives attacked the government plan as inadequate to the task of effective reform. Ryzhkov's plan shifts traditional central planning from an emphasis on heavy industry to consumer goods. It speaks of developing a market but says little about concrete measures for freeing products from the iron control of ministries for free sale on the market. Andreev urged Parliament to express its lack of confidence in the government by asking it to draft a new economic reform plan and to fire the officials who drafted the original version. Just before the vote, Ryzhkov took the floor and in an emotional statement with a cracking voice, rejected a proposal that the plan merely be taken into consideration and asked for a straight yes or no vote. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who was presiding over the session, agreed that Parliament should take a firm decision. But, he added that congressional committees would consider changes in the plan suggested by the deputies. ``It's a political question: Will we support this government, that which it introduced, or will we keep the government in such a state all the time that it cannot start its work?'' Gorbachev asked. The vote on approving the economic plan was 1,532 to 419, with 44 abstensions. Ryzhkov stood and clasped his hands in an expression of victory as deputies applauded approval of the plan. In Sunday's Sovietskaya Rossiya newspaper, Ryzhkov implied he would resign if the deputies did not accept his economic proposal. Asked what would happen if the program did not pass, Ryzhkov said, ``Then other people will work it out. Then, it will not be Ryzhkov going to the rostrum, but somebody else. ``I am responsible for my program, I believe in it, and I will never deny anything that is signed by me. If I ever feel fear, then there is no place for me in the government.'' In other action, the leadership failed to muster the required majority to alter the constitution to allow the Communist Party and other officially approved organizations to continue to fill a third of the Congress seats themselves. The current Constitution guarantees a third of the seats to those groups.
